newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan's Zara in 15 mln dinar capital increase.
newsitem.headline: Jordan's Zara in 15 mln dinar capital increase.

text.p: Jordan's Zara Investments, the leading tourism investment holding company, announced on Tuesday a private placement to raise its capital to 40 million dinars ($56 milllion) by this year, company officials said.
The company's 15 million dinar capital increase will be through a private placement offered to the 147 existing shareholders. The issue has to be covered by November 16, company officials added.

"The capital increase will finance some of the capital costs of our estimated $180 million projects that are due for completion by 1999," said Saleh al-Rifai, general manager of Zara Investments Holdings Company, told Reuters.
Zara, which is listed on the primary market of the Amman Finacial Market (AFM), had approved in an extraordinary AGM last September a capital raise to 40 million dinars from 25 million dinars.
The capital hike will help Zara complete an estimated $180 million dollars of hotel construction projects, the largest private sector hotel construction undertaken in Jordan by a sole firm.
Zara was set up in 1994 by investors and institutions, including a key 16 percent stake by Cairo-Amman Bank and similar stakes by two leading Jordanian investors, Khalil Talhouni and Sabih al-Masri.

The company which pins hopes on a projected tourism boom after Jordan's peace treaty with Israel also acquired a key 27.7 percent stake in the five-star InterContinetal managed hotel owned by Jordan Hotel and Tourism. A $20 expansion programme is underway to add an extra 150 rooms by 1998.
Rifai said Zara had already received a commitment from the IFC, the World Bank's private investment arm, to hold a $3 million stake in its equity capital.
Zara was also negotiating with Arab Bank to enter as a shareholder while also getting financing but no final agreement has been reached yet, Rifai added.
Rifai said IFC had agreed to provide a $15 million loan to the companies three main projects currently being constructed at an estimated over $100 million.

Zara's U.S chain Haytt Regency managed five star 313-room hotel in Amman will be ready by end 1998 at a cost of around $42 million with an adjoining $30 million trade centre building currently under construction. A $35 million 231 room Swiss Moevenpick managed Dead Sea village resort will be opened first quarter 1999.
Zara opened recently its first Swiss Moevenpick managed 179 room hotel in the famed Nabatean city of Petra at a cost of around 14 million dinars.
